jaffa's rating 4paws - he'd love to learn French, and has been practising purring in a French accent !
A small box filled with the keepsakes of a past life is the premise for this beautifully narrated book which is based on the author‚Äôs own interpretation of a discovered box of treasured mementos. This quirky story has been weaved around a lost world of love letters, photographs and keepsakes, and collectively offers a whole new story perspective.
When American academic Trevor Stratton is given the box of relics by his colleague, Josianne Noireau, we are introduced to the life of Louise Brunet, a young Frenchwoman who lost her first love during WW1, and who now lives a vicarious life in post war Paris. The story is dotted throughout with illustrations, and small snippets of intimate information, which together form a story filled with romanticism, and visual appeal.
I loved the way the book was presented, from the French chapter headings, to the availability of QR codes for my Smartphone, all help to make this a deliciously different story, which at times feels like you are reading a very personal memoir.
My feeling is that this book will appeal to readers who enjoy interactive narratives, and who are searching for something ‚Äú just a little bit different".

Picking the right plan for you requires two things: an intimate knowledge of your home‚Äôs typical energy use, and a critical eye on any plan‚Äôs fine print.
Determining the validity of these allegations ultimately rests on the shoulders of the Public Utilities Commission of Texas (PUCT), which has acknowledged ‚Äúconcern‚Äù over the reports. However ‚Äì as a retail electric provider committed to responsible, transparent operations ‚Äì we at Think Energy believe it‚Äôs important for Texas energy consumers to understand the issues at hand before entering into their next supply agreement.
4. Know your current contract terms. Before you shop, know what you already have. (Surprisingly, most people don‚Äôt.) What‚Äôs your kwh rate? Check your electric bill. It may be higher than what‚Äôs available elsewhere. (In Texas, last week it ranged from 4.9 cents to as high as 13.5 cents.) Also call your provider and ask for the date your contract expires. Find out whether your rate is fixed or variable. Start planning a possible switch a month before a contract expires.
Final switch tips. When you make your final selection, don‚Äôt call your current electricity provider to cancel. Sign up with the new company only. Try to sign up at least five to seven days before your plan expires so the overlap between the two billing cycles is negligible. Some people switch too late and pay higher prices during the transition. If you have a smart meter, the state rule is you must be switched within 48 hours. But five to seven days is safer.
Because of this exemption, it's possible to move throughout the state and live under different rules pertaining to your right to choose energy supply. If you're moving to a deregulated area and are just now experiencing your right to choose an electricity provider, it can be a confusing process. But we can teach you how to switch power companies for a smooth transition. Enter your ZIP code above to determine whether you live in a deregulated area.
Due to the increased usage of natural gas immediately after deregulation, new-era energy tools such as wind power and smart-grid technology were greatly aided. Texas' first "renewable portfolio standard" ‚Äî or requirement that the state's utilities get a certain amount of their power from renewable energy like wind ‚Äî was signed into law in 1999, as part of the same legislation that deregulated the electric market.
5Green energy plans are supported 100% by Renewable Energy Certificates (RECs) that are purchased and retired in an amount sufficient to match your annual consumption. RECs are a tradeable, non-tangible energy commodity in the United States that represents proof that 1 megawatt-hour (MWh) of electricity was generated from an eligible renewable energy resource like biomass, hydro, solar or wind. Please see your Terms of Service for more information.
The local electric company is the utility ‚Äì that‚Äôs the company who owns the infrastructure, including the poles and power lines that deliver electricity to your home. They are who you call if your power goes out or there's an emergency. But in almost every city in Texas, you must choose another company to supply that energy, called a Retail Electric Provider (REP). These REPs, like Spark Energy, allow you to choose electricity plans that offer competitive prices and plans to meet your needs.

Opener John Campbell believes working hard on his batting in recent times was the primary reason behind his century yesterday for the Jamaica Scorpions against Trinidad and Tobago Red Force in their sixth round of the CWI-Digicel Four-day Championship at Sabina Park.
The stylish left-hander, in recording his third hundred at the first-class level, belted 155 after resuming the second day of the encounter on 14, as Jamaica, after starting the day on 16 for none, closed on a comfortable 318 for four in their first innings.
Trinidad and Tobago, who won the toss on the opening day, scored a creditable 243 in their first time at bat.
"It's a lot of hard work that I have been putting in," said Campbell, whose previous best knock was 135.
"Since returning to the team after the West Indies 'A' team series against Sri Lanka, I have been getting starts, but been converting. Thankfully, however, this game, and this innings, I have,'' he added.
Resuming with his overnight partner, Trevon Griffith, who eventually made four, Campbell was a picture of poise and panache as he reeled off a number of classy cuts and drives.
He also shared in two valuable partnerships. The first was 157 runs with Brandon King, who in matching Campbell at periods with fours and sixes, went on make 63, while the second consisted of 89 runs with captain, Paul Palmer, who is not out 68.
The in-form Fabian Allen, who is coming back-to-back unbeaten centuries, is the other not-out batsman. He is on seven.
"It is my biggest century and I like this one the most," highlighted the 24-year-old Campbell. "It is also my first first-class century at home, and for that I am really happy.
"It was just me being myself, being positive and picking the right balls. I also choose my bowlers to attack and picked areas in the field to score, and didn't try to go over the men on the boundary, and I think I did well for the most part.''
Meanwhile, looking at the state of the game, Campbell said the Scorpions had the upper hand, and come the third day, he hopes they will be able to drive home their advantage.
"We are in a pretty good position. We have a sizeable lead now of 70-odd with six wickets remaining, with two batsmen who have been in form for us this season at the wicket.
"It's also good to have gotten two batting bonus points in the innings so far, as batting bonus points could play a role for us towards the back end of the season.
"If we could therefore get another two batting bonus points by reaching 400 or 450 runs in our first innings, that would be good for us. Also, any lead of over 100 would be good,'' he added.

With a Mediterranean influence, the Illyria lamp is rich in detail. The central "bead" is laminated in 8 sections of curly maple, separated by walnut inlay. Bigleaf maple burl and walnut medallions are set on each section before turning. The neck and base are similarly sectioned in walnut. The neck section is rough turned to profile, then hand faceted to create a sweeping octagonal shape and to mirror the octagonal plinth. The plinth ring is laid up with the wood's end grain to the outside to add variety in the wood figure.
The conical shade is recommended with this lamp. Panels can either be light (alkyd) or amber (shellac) mica. Also available are birdseye veneer panels. Wood veneers are infused with clear penetrating epoxy and laminated to sheer fiberglass cloth to stabilize and inhibit cracking.
Lamps and shades are fine sanded, oiled to bring out the figure, and finished in catalysed lacquer for a durable finish.

Please note that your requested time may not be available. We will contact you to confirm your final appointment date and time.
...on the shore of Matanzas Bay, St. Augustine, Florida... sits Castillo de San Marcos... the oldest masonry fort in the United States. Designed by Ignacio Daza, the fort was constructed by Spain between the years 1672 and 1695. The fort was briefly named Fort St. Mark, during the English occupation of Florida from 1763 to 1783, until it was returned to Spain, which held on to it until Florida was ceded to the United States in 1821. The fort was then occupied by the United States Army and named Fort Marion. In 1924, the fort was deactivated and declared a National Monument, its name reverting back to the original "Castillo de San Marcos"... and turned over to the United States National Park Service in 1933.

From 8-9 September 2014, a Small and Medium Enterprises (SME) training for Improved Cook Stove (ICS) producers was held at Pakse Hotel in Champasack Province.
The main objective of the training was to provide support to improve the ICS value chain, and to build the capacity of the ICS technical team. Many aspects were covered in the 2-day training from developing business skills and investment and business plan writing to providing a solid understanding of ‚Äòfranchise business models‚Äô and SME registration requirements. The workshop also detailed methods for increasing access to finance to improve production and how to establish a producers association.
The capacity building components also aimed to develop SME practices including how to apply for and manage a loan from local banks. This was identified as the primary skill needed for all producers to develop their business and to be able to build and improve their financial management, producing and marketing skills.
The next plan is to follow up the Business Plan that link to the establishment of the SME Entrepreneur in all three provinces.

Aging is inevitable but with a proper skin care regimen you can delay the signs of aging and keep your skin looking healthy and beautiful. One of the first signs of aging is the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles. Dark spots, enlarged pores and loss of skin elasticity are some of the other signs of aging. Loss of skin elasticity is one of the major reasons that a person looks older than his/her age. When the skin loses elasticity, the skin tends to sag and this is more noticeable along your jaw line and under your eyes. The best way to prevent this is by not only keeping your skin hydrated but by doing regular facial exercises. Limiting sun exposure and wearing a broad-spectrum sunscreen also helps in preventing skin from sagging.
If you are already suffering from sagging skin then there are lots of products available in the market that you can use. But before trying out these expensive beauty products, you can try some home remedies for skin tightening by using ingredients that are available in your pantry or refrigerator. Here are some skin tightening home remedies that you can try.
Sandalwood Mask: Apply a mask on your face by making a paste of sandalwood powder with pure organic rose water. Wash the mask off with cold water when it gets dry. This mask will help to tighten the pores of the skin and also tone up your face.
Egg White Mask: If you are going to a party and want a quick skin tightening home remedy, then here is a good option. Crack an egg and separate the egg white into a bowl. Add a few drops of lemon juice and whisk the egg white until it is light and frothy. Use a brush to apply this mixture on your skin and then let it dry completely. Wash off with lukewarm water and you will immediately see that your skin looks taut and glowing. Enlarged pores are also tightened temporarily by this method.
Milk and Honey Mask: Take two tablespoons of milk and add a few drops of vitamin E oil and organic honey. Apply this mixture on your skin and wash off after 10 minutes. This will not only tighten your skin but also help to get rid of tanning.
Cucumber Mask: Grate a medium-sized cucumber and extract its juice. Add two tablespoons of rosehip oil into the cucumber juice and apply this mixture with the help of a cotton ball. Leave it on for 10 to 15 minutes and then wash off with cold water.
Banana Face Pack: Mash a ripe banana and apply this all over your face and neck area. Leave it on for 15 to 20 minutes and then wash off with cold water. Mashed banana is a very good anti wrinkle treatment as well as one of the most effective ways to tighten skin at home.
Aloe Vera Massage: Massaging your face with fresh aloe vera juice also helps to tighten the skin and provide hydration.
Sugarcane and Turmeric Mask: Another good skin tightening home remedy is to make a mixture of sugarcane juice with a tablespoon of fresh turmeric juice. Apply this mixture on your skin everyday to get the best results.
Tomato Juice Toner: Cut a tomato into half and rub the cut portion into your skin in gentle circular motion. Wash off your face with cold water. With regular use you will find that your skin looks brighter and the pores are also greatly reduced.
Orange and Grape Mask: Mash 4 ‚Äì 5 grapes and mix its pulp with freshly squeezed orange juice. Apply this mixture on your skin and leave it on for 15 to 20 minutes and rinse with cold water.
Avocado Face Pack: Scoop out the pulp of an avocado and add two tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil into it. Refrigerate the mixture for half an hour and then apply this on your face in an even layer. Wash the mask off after 20 minutes and rinse with cold water. The avocado not only tightens skin but also hydrates and moisturizes your skin leaving it smooth.
Yogurt and Lime Face Pack: Make a skin tightening face mask by mixing 2 tablespoons of thick yogurt with the juice of a freshly squeezed lime. Apply this mask on your face and allow it to dry completely before rinsing with cold water.
Papaya and Blueberry Pack: Another great face mask can be made by mashing a piece of overripe papaya with a few blueberries. Papaya will help in exfoliating the skin and blueberries contain antioxidants that helps in fighting free radicals that damage the skin.
Before you try out any skin tightening products or consider laser skin tightening, it is best to try out some of the natural ways to tighten skin. In addition to these treatments, you should also drink adequate amounts of water to keep your body and skin hydrated. If you suffer from stress, go for yoga and meditation and also reduce the intake of coffee and tea. Have a healthy diet with a proper exercise and beauty regimen and you can keep skin aging at bay and have wrinkle free, smooth and supple skin.
In 1970s, a helpless atmosphere was flowing in Asagaya of Tokyo, Japan. Abe (acted by Kenji Mizuhashi) lived with Miyoko (acted by Mary Machida) and got attention by his art comic work ‚ÄúMiyoko asagaya kibun‚Äù (English title: MIYOKO).
But Abe was gradually coming to a dead end in his creative way because he lost the border between his private life and the world of his work. Then, he became a schizoid and repeated to stay in the mental hospital.
The editor (acted by Shiro Sano) who worked for a legendary art comic magazine ‚ÄúMonthly Comic Garo‚Äù could not give up Abe‚Äôs talent and visited Abe‚Äôs place.
[Cinema Today Film News] ‚ÄúMiyoko Asagaya Kibun‚Äù (English title: MIYOKO) which is a nominee for VPRO Tiger Awards of the 39th International Film Festival Rotterdam was screened officially on the spot. Even though it screened early in the day, 10:30 am in the morning, most of seats were filled with audience.
The film brought the Best New Actress award to Mary Machida, a leading actress, in the 31th Yokohama Film Festival, is decided to reshow in Sangenjaya Central Theater in Tokyo from March 6th, and is spreading good valuation slowly. In the spot, Rotterdam, the film is now widely talked of as a possible Grad Prize due to the good complicated story of the short fiction comic work whose model is a cult comic artist, Shinichi Abe‚Äôs wife and his real life.
‚ÄúMiyoko Asagaya Kibun‚Äù (English title: MIYOKO) which Mr. Tsubota directed as the first film for the theater was awarded Blue Chameleon Award of Cinema Digital Seoul Film Festival in Korea. The film is one of the Grand Prize works which each judge of four categories selected for the Grand Prize from 15 nominees. The festival gathers new Asian director‚Äôs works‚Ä¶ The small budget film, ‚ÄúMIYOKO‚Äù that cleared pinches of suspension for shooting is making a round of screening in all over the world since releasing of last year‚Äôs summer. The comic artist, Shinichi Abe, is the model who has published his works centering on the comic magazine named ‚ÄúGaro‚Äù since ‚Äô70s. The film is reflecting a binding relationship between a main character, Abe himself, and his wife based on Abe‚Äôs works which draw the relation with the wife without reserve. The film including humor and eroticism attracted Korean audience. In the screening process, the film gathered high valuations with words ‚Äúthe film is outstanding with the expression of mixture of falsehood and truth and Miyoko‚Äôs portrait which supports the artist, her husband Abe, with selfless devotion.
Graduated Tama Art University. Mr. Tsubota has also dealt with commercial films and productions of TV programs. The DVD of ‚ÄúMIYOKO‚Äù is on sale from Kinokuniya Book Store.
I was born in 1955 and graduated Meiji University on Literature in Japan and Borough of Manhattan Community College with graduation with honor on Writing and Literature.
I have had a long time for serialization for the Yahoo Internet Guide of Japan over 5years and 50 times.
During three decades in the Japanese publishing industry, I have published over 7 books as an author and 4 books as an editor. I published two books from Kodansha which is the biggest publisher in Japan and the most authoritative publisher, especially Japanese. And I have contributed as a writer to the Weekly Economist which is published by Mainichi NewsPapers, one of the three big newspapers in Japan. I live in Brooklyn, New York and started my translator career since 2011. Recently, I have been working for Vice Japan as an English-to-Japanese translator.
Durgadas speak about Ramdev bringing back Traditional Yoga of the Vedas, as opposed to the western pasteurised Yoga systems.
There are some changes in modern India. Baba Ramdev has given Yoga a new resurrection and along with this, PM Narendra Modi has started transforming the nation and also is sympathetic to sciences such as Yoga and Ayurveda.
While Baba Ramdev has been criticised for much in India, his views and teachings on Yoga and Ayurveda have brought back to India, the same kind of resurgence that we saw back in the 12th Century AD, with Hatha-Yogis such as Gorakshanatha and others who started this tradition, based on the ancient aspect of Dhanurveda or Vedic martial arts (lit. "The science of the bow". )
Sri ‚Ä™‚ÄéGorakshanatha inspired Bappa Rawal and his ‚Ä™‚ÄéGurkhas (named after Gorakshanatha) to go west and defend India against attacks of Arab and other Muslim invaders.
To accomplish this, the forceful or ‚Ä™‚ÄéHatha-‚Ä™Yoga was taken up, as it was by Parashurama thousands of years beforehand in southern India, to train warriors with flexible muscles and systems as ‚Ä™brahmacharya (celibacy) and shat-kriyas (cleansing actions) to retain their vitality and cleanse their bodies to avoid any wavering from dharma while fighting and being impervious to distractions of sex or women or other allures, which made them single-focused powerful "super-warriors". The militant Gurkhas later migrated into Nepal. ‚Ä™Krishnamacharya, the Guru of ‚Ä™Iyengar himself learnt from a Gurkha in the Himalayas in the system of Hatha-Yoga that has been populated across the globe as the "Mysore" and other schools. It is people like the Rajputs and Gurkhas today, like the southern Kalari masters, who are the people traditionally created and cultivated through Hatha-Yoga.
It was hence also used, since time immemorial, to cure various diseases. Along with this was also developed the science if Rasa-shastra or Alchemy, the science of Mercury (rasa or parada). This dates back to the Rig Veda and the various Soma preparations that were both mineral or alchemical and also confections (avalehas, rasayanas). Both Sushruta and Charaka Samhitas by 1500BCE also mention use of heavy metals and mineral preparations. These were often used along with Yoga therapies for more difficult and so-called incurable diseases and disorders.
I don't believe there is really an asadhya (incurable) disease. In ‚Ä™Yoga, the higher side of ‚Ä™Ayurvedic healing, we can choose to prolong the body and heal anything or choose to allow the body to die. Much depends on our state in karmic evolution and our personal situations. Many Yogis rejuvenated their bodies and is stated some, like Chauranginatha even grew limbs, let alone healing of organs and such. Others as Chyavana reversed the aging process through ‚Ä™rasayana (rejuvenation). All is possible. Sadly however, this higher or para-yoga is hardly unknown today, giving way to the commercialism of Yoga! The Ashwins here however, are also the pranic and other keys to this, through their symbolism embodied in the Rig Veda (note my book Ashwini Rahasya).
What Baba Ramdev however has brought back to India and the world is this sacred synthesis of Yoga and Ayurveda as sister-sciences as an integral science. His knowledge of aspects such as prana is also important. Deep within the recesses of the spiritual sushumna-nadi in the spine also lies the pranic-nerve, of which, when disrupted, can cause diseases. The body requires oxygenation of the blood and also organs, of which our current tamasic lifestyle smothers. We have bad prana or air in our facilities - we use electrical forms of heating and cooling, what to speak about such dramatic drops in temperature do to out health directly (such as stepping out of an A/C room in India into 30 degree heat!). Remember that climatic and seasonal changes affect health in such manners also - yet we deliberately change these in our lifestyles and cause diseases - what to speak of the false quality of air (polluted inside and out). The ancient world also had more trees and forests to propagate better atmospheres and performances of Agni-Hotras and larger-scale ones (known as Ashwamedhas - which are not horse-sacrifices!).
The personal Ashwamedha was actually an offering of pranayama into the inner-fire to purify it (prana-shuddhi). Ashwa is also a Vedic synonym for prana, medha meaning both wisdom and also implying an offering. Horses also personified indriyas or senses, as in Kathopanishad. Here, their offering was represented by various animals and limbs symbolically, that was later taken more literally (see my article No Meat-Eating in the Vedas on this note). Most Vedic mantras, in fact, can be used and turned into pranayama-mantras and when intoned correctly, can also purify out nadis or subtle nerves and meridians in the body, the subtle channels behind disease.
Some have doubted Ramdev's claims that Yogic techniques can cure renal failure, AIDS, cancer and other severe diseases. Such criticisms usually also include a bias towards allopathy and it's false application of dietary and specific regimes. For disorders as Sciatica and Arthritis for example, which surgery is an option, but not a definite cure, analgesic drugs are it's best "cure". Digestive disorders such as Crohn's and Coeliac, it has little hope for, as also advanced Diabetes, whereas Ayurveda and Yoga first look at dietary factors and ahara - what we are taking into the body in forms of toxic foods.
As an example, the classical texts tell us that damage near marmas or vital-points, even surgery or heat - says Sushruta, can cause damage to the organs they relate to. The feet are connected to the nerves in the eyes. I have found a number of people suffering from Glaucoma and Cataracts, upon questioning, have had acupuncture at some time on their feet for other ailments. Acupuncture has short-term positive effects (like allopathy), but long-term deranging effects. Ayurveda looks at the long-term. There are also traditional or classical medicine practitioners in China, outside the common TCM system, who argue that Mao and others doctored such systems (while it was used in some communities, as also in India).
The issue is that modern medicine derived a great degree of its background from the ancient Greek and Ayurvedic systems, the latter of which came into the West possibly as early as the Greeks, who had contact with India long before the Macedonian Empire of Alexander the Great, and also translations of later texts via the Arabs, which included the transmission of Indian knowledge such as integers, zero and the numerical system, as well as advancements in astronomy and other areas of mathematics.
Yet, the West, at least since Constantine and the invention of Christianity, has only had a partial-system, which further became reduced. Important techniques such as Yoga were rejected, as also the rational approach of Ayurveda towards fields such as psychiatry (of which Ayurveda also includes spiritual aspects, with both spiritual and rational treatments, but symptoms differ). While the Church adopted the purely spiritual approach and a Catholic remedy for this (exorcism), the rationalists in Europe rejected all spirituality and ties with the Church, it's arch-enemy and went purely rational. Both sides however were extremes, while Ayurveda took the middle-ground, encompassing both sides, but in a more sophisticated and elaborate manner, which exists to this day.
As a result, the approach of disease in Ayurveda is more complex. Ayurveda pioneered many advancements in modern medicine, such as the diagnosis of Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes, surgical clips for the bowels by using ants, anesthesia, vaccination against smallpox, plastic surgery of which the British first noted in the Mysore wars by southern Ayurvedic physicians and was later taken up by Joseph Constantine Carpue who introduced it into Britain, cataract surgery and surgical removal of kidney stones, among others. If we also carefully examine the Ayurvedic classics, we note the preliminary and post-operative procedures were much more complex and involved more patient care and rest than we allow today with out quick-fix culture, aimed at freeing up hospital beds, rather than patient recuperation. There is also little in the way of rejuvenation or rasayana, the science of the celestial Soma.
Even Yoga itself, the West has turned into a chiropractic-model and a culture or lifestyle for the elite, rather than one aimed at transcending the ego! In most cases, Yoga teachers take up Yoga, as with Pilates and other trends as Zumba, to adapt to the materialistic chardonnay-socialist culture of cheese and wine, over austerity, service to humanity and deep dedication. Concepts such as bhakti or devotion and surrender to a deity, let alone pujas or offerings and reverence of the deities and Rishis of tradition are reduced down to to a few pictures or pretty-statues of Shiva-Nataraja or Ganesha in a room. Asana or posture is quickly taken up, dismissing the deeper value of preliminary limbs such as yamas and niyamas that actually took traditional Yogis decades - sometimes lifetimes, to master (which is why many tried to prolong the body to live 1,000 years or reduced their karmas and assumed multiple births in continuation). The idea of the Ten Sikh Gurus of Sikhism and the Dashavatara or ten incarnations of Vishnu in Hinduism also reflect this, representing mastery over the 5 yamas and 5 niyamas of Patanjali. Yoga today also has no dharana - no concentration, as there is no pratyahara - no withdrawing from (toxic) influences.
As I explain to students, while many talk about ahimsa, how can one really go to the next yama, let alone jump to asana, before first understanding it's complexity, which includes daihika (bodily), vachina (spoken) and manasika (mental) ahimsa or non-violence, not just to others, but to one's own body? Unless we adopt the pratyahara of abstaining from foods, substances and actions or lifestyle regimes that are not agreeable to our Ayurvedic Prakriti or constitution, our Manasika Prakriti or mental constitution and our Vikriti, our disorders - how can we state we know about and have actually perfected the first tenant of Yoga - ahimsa? Are we not doing harm to the body?
Take an example. The number of people I see that I speak about incompatible food-combinations causing ama or toxins and others such as avoiding cooking honey (which is toxic when cooked to the body), that are amazed and violate these rules, is astounding. Simply reducing these, alcohol and red meats in our diets is a start - even if we don't eat for our dosha per se (which this is recommended!). Most Yoga teachers and circles with a wine culture are actually daihika-himsikas - those who cause injury to the body and thus violating ahimsa!
Ahimsa is also not about non-injury alone. It means we should not attack or injure another party and try and avoid it at all costs. However, if we are attacked, we must take up arms to defend ourselves, such as examples as Arjuna, Sri Krishna, Sri Rama, Hanuman and even the Brahmin Parashurama show. The Rishis also defended themselves, as we see with the wars of Vasishtha vs Vishwamitra! If we perform non-action and do not fight or stand up for dharma - the foundations upon which ahimsa rests, society's ahimsa wanes and is uprooted, such has occurred in South Americans who have lost their traditions to Catholicism and the Middle-East and Central-Asia, which have lost theirs to the aggression of Islam. India however, revolted - starting with the actual science of Yogis themselves with militant-Yogis as Gorakshanatha, Rajputs and the Gurkhas. This science began with Parashurama himself and the asanas or postures formed, as they did with Gandharvaveda or music and dancing, part of the vyayamas or exercise-regimes for warriors, for agility etc. in battle. While used to cure diseases, it was tailored.
I began practising Yoga at a tender age of about 8 or 9 years old, when I began taking up martial arts. I did not wait until my thirties and decide that I wanted to become a Yoga teacher - what is really an asana teacher! I still have no ambitions for such. This is also the point here - we have forgotten the true foundations of Yoga-dharma itself and westernised Yoga, molded it into the fabric of allopathy and turned it into a culture of bodily-preservation for vanity, rather than the Yogic view to extend our lives in order to work out our karmas. There is also still, even in western Yoga circles, a reluctance for this self-responsibility of oriental faiths and still a culture of blame on the outside world for our weaknesses and failures, for our own actions we cannot come to terms with. Such is also due to what I class as the "Christocentric samskaras", the cultural residual substratum of almost 2,000 years of Christian-dominated thinking. It is much like a turmeric stain - one can wash and wash, but in vain, as some residue still remains of the yellowish hue!
This is where Baba Ramdev comes in. His Yoga is the original Indian-Yoga system that isn't a synthesis of East and West, it is a powerful and energetic thunderbolt of tradition that is at odds with the ego of western views of Yoga and how Yoga 'should be'. While we have the western experts from Max Muller to Michael Witzel who believe no Indian knows their own Hindu history better than they do as they look at it from afar - so also we have our bored housewives in the West with their Country-Club cultures who believe Yoga is however they see fit (reminiscent of Pentecostals and Southern Baptist preachers!). By contrast, Ramdev's Yoga is one of practice and personal effort, the result of which, if adhered to, is highly rewarding, both spiritually and physically!
And that is the difference between East and West - personal effort vs effort of others. The West, including the Arabs gained their riches by plundering the wealth of other nations and then turning cultures against each-other, deeming them as heathens, while stepping back and not admitting any foul-play on their part. This ranges from the slavery of Blacks in the Americas to the Aryan-Dravidian divide and Aryan-Invasion Theory of India and racial theories. It is venomous in the Western mind to accept one's own actions have resulted in anything but instruments in some fantastical "divine plan"!.
Criticisms of traditional Yoga will remain, especially with traditional and outspoken teachers as Ramdev and others. This is as, once again, the personal effort of the orient clashes with the silver-platter culture of the west. We can see this in hardworking Indian and east-Asian migrants in Western countries who do better in business than local residents, due to their work-ethics, compared to the laziness of the west, by comparison, especially British colonies! Much was the same logic that underlined the Nazi fascism and hatred of Jews in Europe. It was more jealousy rather than hatred - more based on a Christocentric sense of entitlement rather than gains due to personal works or efforts and actions (karmas), on both a physical and spiritual level.
The Arab and Turkic plunder of temples in India was also similar. Islamic invaders could not imagine how such wealth and opulence, such magnificent buildings and riches were in a nation of "heathens" or pagans, compared to their own God-beloved culture of Allah! As a result, it must be that Allah requires the plunder and destruction of such people and their evil riches, taken forcefully instead for his chosen people across Central Asia and the Middle-East! Thus, this underlying logic, while removed from religion, is still present today in the western minds, Middle-Eastern and European! It is a samskara hard to scrub-out and is masked by a pseudo-acceptance of Yoga, Ayurveda and such, as well as a culture of reinventing such in the West, as a sign of cultural dominance over the Indian, as was also historical!
This is also why such egos, especially those clones of such Victorian attitudes in India - where they perhaps are best preserved today more than anywhere else, clash with the likes of Baba Ramdev! We must also remember that Baba Ramdev forms a part of the Arya-Samaj Movement in India, started by the Vedic reformer, Maharishi Dayananda Sarasvati. A powerful opponent of Islam and Christianity, he was a first to include a detailed criticism of these faiths in his work Satyarth Prakash (The Light of Truth) and also expound the Vedas along symbolic lines as opposed to those of the 14th-Century Sayanacharya and western scholars as Muller who followed his lead. He was also the first to proclaim Swaraj or Self-rule for India and Hindi as the national language - long before Gandhi. Many Arya-Samajis lost their lives in independence struggles, long before Gandhi ever came on the scene. Scholars such as Sri Aurobindo were also profoundly influenced by Dayananda and his Vedic wisdom, including his claim of ancient technology in the Vedas:
"‚Äò There is then nothing fantastical in Swami Dayananda‚Äôs idea that the Veda contains the truths of science. I will even add my own conviction that the Veda contains other truths of science which the modern world does not at all possess, and, in that case, Swami Dayananda has rather under-stated than over-stated the depth and rage of the Vedic Wisdom. Immediately after the character of the Veda is fixed in the sense Swami Dayananda gave to it, the merely ritual, mythological, polytheistic interpretation of Sayanacharya collapses, and the merely meteorological and materialistic European interpretation collapses. We have, instead, a real scripture, one of the World‚Äôs sacred books, and the divine word of a lofty and noble religion‚Äô."
"In the matter of Vedic interpretation I am convinced that whatever may be the final complete interpretation, Dayananda will be honoured as the first discoverer of the right clues. Amidst the chaos and obscurity of old ignorance and age-long misunderstanding his was the eye of direct vision that pierced to the truth and fastened on that which was essential. He has found the keys of the doors that time had closed and rent asunder the seals of the imprisoned fountains."
There were also many Western scholars who appreciated ancient Indian thought and philosophy, who also included J. Robert Oppenheimer, Nikola Tesla, Carl Jung and even Friedrich Nietzsche! Today, Physicists such as Fritjof Capra and Fred Alan Wolf have also looked to ancient Indian philosophies for answers to modern scientific questions of the wisdom of the ancient Yogis!
With such strong personalities behind Ramdev however, it is hence unlikely he will be silent, if we has a point to make. And why should he? The ideals of the modern world that Yogis are soft-spoken, jovial and silent on political issues certainly do not match the great teachers of Yoga's tradition such as Parashurama, Rishi Yajnavalkya, Bhishmacharya and Sri Krishna, who were very outspoken personalities and also political figures in their own right!
While the civilised aspect of debate existed in ancient India with philosophers as in ancient Greece, we expect that modern Yogis do not debate, and we accept, without question, their words and criticise others in the media. Such is the asuric form of debate, bereft of the Vedic tenets, which include pratyaksha (direct perception), anumana (inference), upamana (comparison) and shabda (spoken word / scriptural evidences or aitihya - historical accounts), not simply who can shout the loudest or hurl the most insults or defamatory columns in the Hindustan Times!
We also forget that Ramdev is a man who lives a Yogic lifestyle and has helped hundreds of thousands of people across the globe with his Yoga camps. His hospitals in India and Yoga mission has also been a blessing and has also helped Indians realise what Yoga actually is, to take it up, and also the glory of Ayurveda, beyond a mere few village herbs! He has released many classical preparations and has rejuvenated Ayurveda in Northern India, especially in urban areas which are becoming increasingly westernised and destroying their native roots. Others such as Dr. Partap Chauan of Jiva Ayurveda have done great efforts to bring Ayurvedic remedies to the masses in India through the TV media, as Ramdev has also done.
For me, Baba Ramdev is not simply a great Yogi and Guru, but also epitomises what it is to be a Yogi. I have seen this in the spirit of Sri Aurobindo and also Maharishi Dayananda and Swami Vivekananda. It is not a silent personality, but what Dr. David Frawley (Pandit Vamadeva Shastri) calls an "Intellectual Kshatriya" or warrior.
This is about Hindus standing up for what they believe in and defending the dharma, not simply bowing or caving into peer-pressures of the modern world and its perverted and materialistic changes. In medieval India, it was also the Brahmins who preserved diligently, the ancient Vedic teachings, against all odds. It was the likes of Manidhara and Sayanacharya that dared to write commentaries on the Rig Veda, thousands of years after the Brahmanas and Yaskacharya. It is this Yogic spirit that has immortalised Hanuman, Parashurama, Sri Krishna, Shivaji, Maharani of Jhansi and the Sikh Gurus and martyrs. It is not about sipping wine and telling your students about ahimsa and the greatness of Gandhi (which appears to have been taken from Ben Kingsley's role in the movie than reality!).
A Yogi is not a conformist - he is a rebel. he exists outside of society, as the sannyasi - one who has renounced all ties. Sannyasa also means a comatosed-state in Ayurveda, which refers to one's loss of consciousness from the ordinary, which is also represented by both the mission and vision of the Yogi.
Baba Ramdev, like the ancient Vedic Rishis as Bharadvaja, Vishwamitra and Vasishtha is a political figure, a spiritual guide, a Yogi, an Ayurvedic practitioner and upholder of the sacred Vedic traditions, by definition of the authors of the tradition itself, not of the fantasy of the modern mind! As such, we can ask for no better defender of the Yogic faith and for Hinduism itself, which denies nobody - as the Cochin Jews and the largest number of Zoroastrians (Parsis) who exist now in greater numbers in Mumbai, not their original homeland of Iran! It is this spirit of defense, instigated by Gorakshanatha and the Hatha-Yogis that saved these people and provided preservation and refuge for both India and others, that embodies the real spirit of Yoga by tradition.
And if Baba Ramdev is guilty of that, of which he is, then let him remain a rebel and trouble-maker, for he is possibly our closest living example of Yoga's personification or avatar today!

The 3rd annual Denver International Festival is a summer celebration of the best traditional food, music, art, beer and wine from Colorado and abroad. Come eat, drink, dance and play on Saturday, August 4th 2018 from 11am - 7pm in the heart of downtown Denver at Civic Center Park.
Enjoy the sounds of live cultural rhythms, vibrant International flavors, traditional artwork, and a beer garden just a few short steps from the State Capitol inside Civic Center Park. This event is FREE to the public and will feature over 25+ Performers, 20+ Food Trucks, 50+ Vendors, a Beer/Wine Tasting, a Kids Village and more.
The Denver International Festival will not only be the city‚Äôs largest celebration of global FOOD + MUSIC + ART but it also giving back to less fortunate communities in our own backyard and around the world through our annual benefit concert. The evening concert will feature a headliner in addition to a diversely talented group of homegrown musicians.
Shake your hips to the sounds of Salsa, feel the bass of live African drums, get down to the rhythm of Reggae and rock out with live performers. The music stage will feature tantalizing live bands, DJ‚Äôs and Dance performances from countries around the world.
Smell the aroma of Asian and African spices. Sample the savory flavors of the Mediterranean and Europe. Indulge in the delicious dishes of Latin America. Take your taste buds for a journey and experience various traditional food from 30+ international restaurants and food trucks. Also featuring a beer garden serving international brews, wine and cocktails.
Feast your eyes on live art from featured artists, take part in an interactive art mural, and browse through a visual and hand crafted art market place of some of Colorado's most talented artists.
Bring the family and enjoy engaging and collaborative activities for the kids as they have fun learning about cultures from around the world. Activities include face painting, balloon animals, bouncy houses, and art stations.

Took a short and quick weekend turnaround trip to Kuala Lumpur in the mid of August. It has been about one year since the last visit.
To begin the trip with a slight flight delay on a evening flight out isn‚Äôt much of a good thing. The flight despite being 30 minutes delay from the scheduled 9:15pm departure was retimed to 9:145pm. Hence, arriving at KL at 10:45pm. Took an hour to clear immigration and manage to get some light food as there were shops still operating and Glad there was the option of KLIA Ekspress to KL Sentral. It would have been wise to stay at the hotels near KL Sentral ‚Äì such as Hilton KL; if take evening flights out. However, being a first time evening travel out, that was something I had miscalculated. So I took a Grab ride to the Holiday Inn express KLCC.
Kl has always been a place for food and shopping. However, it doesn‚Äôt stop at shopping for me. It‚Äôs worth checking out how shopping malls are doing ‚Äì especially Pavilion and lot 10.
Visited Jogoya (Starhill Gallery) for their buffet lunch (RM122 per pax), and had seafood dinner at Kai Seng Seafood Restaurant.
So at the end of the trip, was a smoother ride back with the convenience of in-town check in at KL Sentral for Malaysia Airlines. If you are taking Malindo Air or Cathay Pacific, this option is available too.

Calculate interest only mortgage payments by inserting the appropriate loan values in the calculator fields below. The monthly savings on interest only loans may be significant compared to traditional fixed rate mortgages so you owe it to yourself to learn more about the benefits & risks of interest only home loan programs.
What is an Interest Only Loan? An Interest-Only loan is a home loan program where you have an option to make "interest-only" payments for a defined period of the loan. The term "interest-only" does not mean not mean a consumer will never have to repay the principal amount of the loan. Usually there is a term in which you will pay only interest. After that term, you would then have to pay both interest and principle. Interest only loans generally use a variable interest rate.
I try to write a short essay or two every day. I have been doing this for at least a decade. Sometimes I work on my poetry. This takes WAY longer. For anyone who attempts this art form, who is not blessed with The Gift, my heart goes out. You wake up in the middle of the night with ONE word that insists on inserting itself into your poem, and that changes the entire energy of the verse. Oh well. Maybe that's why you will notice I am wrtiing essays late at night, because once the Muse wakes you up in the middle of a succulent dream, insisting that you must add that one word, she departs leaving you wide awake and essaying.
All this got me wondering...Maybe I should try to write day essays. No better time than the present. Today it's pouring here in Asheville. Great day to take some time off. So, follwoing my own sage advice, I wrote today's essay for Active Rain...e a r l y.
OK! I don't care, I will post my great essay on how come real estate professionals need to know about GREEN STUFF. I don't care about the Points! I care about getting the word out to my colleagues. BUT wait a minute. If I value what I have to say, and I think YOU who read what I have to say might value it, shouldn't I refrain from posting this amazing peice until Monday? when it can get the credit it deserves? Isn't this a test of how I value myself?
What if I applied this lesson to my real state practice? Shouldn't I NOT work with people who do NOT value me and what I have to say? A Relevant Topic this week here on the Featured Side. http://activerain.com/blogsview/17188/-Murphy-s-Law What kind of Muse hangs around during the day, anyway?
Here's what I want to know...Can I still get a STAR? if anyone happens to read this, can you still give me a star?
I think I shall return to my nighttime ramblings. I'll save the non-pointed days for rants...and HUMOR.

Hidden in the center of Sioux Falls is Kenwood Manor Apartments, one of the city's cleanest, quietest, and best kept secrets. The park-like setting is enhanced by the calm and quiet atmosphere.
Kenwood Manor Apartments are located in the west central part of the city with direct access to 18th Street, just six blocks west of Sanford Hospital. The complex is set far back from the 18th Street thoroughfare with no through traffic, making this an isolated island of quietness.
Kenwood has great access to everything in the city. Sanford Hospital is just six blocks away, and the V. A. Hospital is four blocks. Avera McKennan Hospital is just ten minutes away, just off of 18th Street. We are also close to Augustana University and the University Of Sioux Falls. Sherman Park, the bike trails, W. H. Lyons Fairgrounds, and the new Sanford Events Center are all in the neighborhood.
Built in 1950, these buildings are constructed of concrete and steel throughout. Every wall, floor, and ceiling is constructed specifically with noise reduction in mind. Sound transmission from apartment to apartment is virtually nonexistent.
Kenwood has been around for over 65 years, so consequently, the grounds are full of mature trees and well-established vegetation. Kenwood Manor gives you the feeling that you are living in one of Sioux Falls‚Äô older parks.

Villains, you gotta love 'em. After all, the most heroic stories are those that involve beating the vilest of villains, and having a great antagonist is often what makes the story worth telling in the first place. Villainous takes a completely different twist to be original, instead of being the hero, you get to play the role of the villain. And thus beings your quest to raid towns, attack castles and ultimately, raise as much infamy across the land as possible.
A true evil mastermind should always remember that the end goal is the most important thing of all. It is not how wicked, or cruel, or mischievous you are, it is about getting your goals done. And for the most evil wizard in the world, you have a very simple goal to finish: successfully raid towns over and over again. To do so, you must successfully send your goblin raiders into the heart of the human's settlements and have these little buggers do your dirty work for you. But in between your goblins and the human's treasure-filled coffers, you need to deal with a ton of defensive tower structures that are armed to the teeth with a variety of weapons designed to send your troops back in a body bag.
The game looks a lot like a tower defense game, and in many ways, even the concept is the same. But what differs is the side you are on. Instead of building towers and upgrading your defenses, you are the one sending in goblins, golems and other creatures -waves if you will, that are all aimed at only one thing: raiding human towns. Goblin raiders are not exactly the best units to send against a well defended town -after all, all they can do is pillage, plunder and philfer. To help keep them alive, you need to send in specialists and probably toss in a few supportive evil spells of your own.
And thus comes the strategic portion of the game. Villainous requires its players to think carefully when it comes to sending in troops. You cannot just send in a regiment of 12 goblin raiders and expect them to hold out well against a rain of arrows and cannon fire. You will need to bring healing casters, golems that emit a protective aura, turtles that distract enemy fire, and many more abilities that will ensure that your raiders make it to town in tip top shape (or basically, alive).
There are three main phases in the game: upgrading, deployment and attacking. For the upgrade phase, players must delegate and portion their infamy points for buying upgrades. Upgrades will do a variety of things ranging from unlocking new spells to improving troop stats to increasing your army size and more. Naturally, it is best to focus upgrades on skills and features that you actually use in combat. The game will provide plenty of chances for farming infamy in the later stages, but it is still best to be careful with the use of your resources.
The deployment phase is actually a lot trickier than one would think. Here, you will be able to decide what troops you would be sending in. Each troop type has its own specialty and purpose and ultimately, your main goal is for all the support troops to be able to keep your goblins alive. Making sure that your formation is working successfully towards this goal is a combination of luck, skill and preparation. The most difficult thing to consider here is the fact that once you decide on a final deployment scheme, you can no longer alter the arrangement and positioning of your army. The key here is to focus on a setup that will not just withstand a few waves, but one that has plenty of staying power. Try to foresee which units are likely to die first (usually the turtles) and plan ahead for how the arrangement of troops will work once the first ones fall. Also, another thing to consider here is the area of effect for your units with aura bonuses. Healing and defensive auras are crucial for helping keep your army alive and kicking for many waves, so be sure that they cover the right units when you send them out.
Try to prevent your gold plated jewelry from being in contact with detergents, perfumes and lotions and be careful with excessive friction. To keep your pieces full of brightness you can occasionally rub them using a dry cloth. In case you notice the gold is damaged, do not worry, you can always gold plated them again. Don‚Äôt forget my jewels are handmade and they might present slight differences compared to the original design in the picture.

Almost everyone who ventured west past 40th Street during our time at Penn surely remembers the phrase, ‚ÄúSee You in Church!‚Äù uttered by Joe Murphy, aka Murph, of Murphy‚Äôs Tavern fame as you exited the bar late on Saturday night (or early Sunday morning). Situated at the northeast corner of 44th and Spruce, Murphy‚Äôs Tavern was a favorite local and campus bar. We asked classmates to share their memories.
He was always happy to see us‚Ä¶.gave a great deal on pitchers and what was that red drink we got there? I don‚Äôt remember what it was called.
Julie: Yes! The Skylab! The bar was gross, but Murph was always happy to have us (even those of us with bad fake IDs).
What can I say about Murph and Murphy‚Äôs Tavern? It was the quintessential bar, and one my friends and I preferred over any other establishment around campus. It had everything we wanted from a bar, and nothing we disliked. Memories are hazy at this point, but I distinctly remember that there was always great music. It wasn‚Äôt small, but it wasn‚Äôt so big that you felt like you couldn‚Äôt see and interact with everyone there on any given night. It had the perfect balance of intimacy and yet wasn‚Äôt too claustrophobic. It had zero pretension, but wasn‚Äôt a dump ‚Äî it had the perfect vibe, and I would have been thrilled to find a bar exactly like Murph‚Äôs at any point in my 20s to hang out in. Murph‚Äôs had an iconic and unique drink, the Skylab, that was the perfect drink for college students because it was not too expensive, it was full of alcohol, it tasted great, it had a great name, and was indigenous to Murph‚Äôs and only Murph‚Äôs.
Over everything, though, Murph‚Äôs had Murph, who was the quintessential Irish bar owner. Friendly, gregarious, always welcoming of his regulars, but happy to have newcomers. Anyone coming into his bar immediately felt at home. Murph had a great schtick, mostly because it wasn‚Äôt schtick for him, it was completely and totally authentic.
Josh sent this photo saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm disowning my friends for not including me in this picture. I was with them at Murph‚Äôs that morning, so I‚Äôm not sure how I missed being in this photo, but I will never fully forgive them.‚Äù
Murph‚Äôs ‚ÄúSee You In Church‚Äù that he said to everyone as they left his bar may have led to Jef‚Äôs eventual marriage to his wife, Deb Brown. As I recall, Deb was a columnist for the DP, and named her column ‚ÄúSee You In Church‚Äù. Jef and I didn‚Äôt know Deb at that point, but we thought her picture was cute (as much as one could see of a one square inch black and white photo in the DP), and that she had to be super-cool to name her column after Murph‚Äôs tag line. Jef eventually pursued Deb, and the rest is history. I don‚Äôt know if Jef and Deb consider Murph responsible in any way for their relationship, but I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised to know that there are many couples who are still together who met in some small or big way because of Murph‚Äôs. What held true for Jef and me looking at Deb‚Äôs column still holds true today ‚Äî anyone who ‚Äúgot‚Äù Murph‚Äôs was our kind of person, and that‚Äôs all anyone can ask for from their favorite college bar.
What happened to Murphy‚Äôs Tavern? After multiple Liquor Control Board violations, Murphy‚Äôs was forced to close after a judge refused to renew their liquor license in January, 1997 (as detailed in this DP article). Now the location is the site of Local 44, a ‚Äúneighborhood beer joint.‚Äù

Jewish Issues Watchdog: Media solidarity with murderous Palestinian knife-wielders, mixed with callousness towards innocent Israelis' lives
Media solidarity with murderous Palestinian knife-wielders, mixed with callousness towards innocent Israelis' lives
October was a bloody month in Israel, with over 50 terror attacks, mostly involving stabbings, but also using firearms and vehicles.
Many of the Palestinian perpetrators died in the attacks, some were teens, motivated by religious incitement and lies concerning the site known as al-Aqsa to Muslims and Temple Mount to Jews.
‚ÄúWhat we have witnessed these past weeks has looked like solidarity with murderous Palestinian knife-wielders, mixed with callousness towards innocent Israelis' lives.‚Äù
Here in London, the past few weeks have felt like a veil was lifted over political-correctness and a veneer of journalistic practice with regards to Israel. This was no Gaza operation, not a drone war, nor an exchange of unequal firepower. The facts were clear and simple: Israelis, from children to the elderly, were being murdered in broad daylight in towns across the country.
Yet the media does not seem to get it right even under these circumstances. Headlines still run as "Israeli police shoot Palestinian", then change to "Palestinian shot in knife attack", and again to "Woman who planned knife attack shot dead" (she didn't just plan it, she actually carried it out). An Israeli whose car is stoned with rocks steps out and "pays with his life for attacking Palestinian trucks", while a terrorist "becomes seventh Palestinian killed by security forces after Jerusalem stabbing".
All of the above headlines are real, and all were subsequently corrected; some of them undergoing three or four different versions, reflecting the clear fact that editors understood that they did not make sense, simply did not reflect reality on the ground. Yet these corrections ensued, week after week, as if media outlets were unwilling to accept reality and forgo their automatic mode of reporting on the region, in which Palestinians must play the role of victims, and Israelis the aggressors.
Anti-Israel groups also seemed confused by the situation, and so they did the only thing they know how to do ‚àí call for a protest outside the Israeli Embassy. Under the vague banner of "Protest for Palestine", last week we saw the familiar scenes of Hamas and Hezbollah flags, and of people telling an Israeli journalist that "all Zionists should be killed". Thankfully, his equipment wasn't trashed this time, as it was in last month's "peaceful protest".
Countless headlines were corrected this month, nearly one for every deadly terror attack in Israel. Meanwhile, Palestinian incitement was dismissed by some as "an Israeli line", a "distraction".
Radical clerics brandishing knives and holding up explosive belts, Hamas spokesmen acting as cheerleaders for terror attacks, and Palestinian radio playing songs of praise to the "martyrs", were of little interest to a media focused only on Israeli actions.
The willingness to disregard reality, to display this level of animosity toward Israel at a time when its civilians were facing a wave of rampant terror, sends a clear message: "Your lives are of no interest to us".
Unfortunately, reality doesn't conform to the attitude of the media, as we've seen in Syria, where civilians continue to die regardless of scant media coverage, or Gaza, whose population continues to suffer under Hamas even today.
When we read headlines focusing on Israel's in-the-moment response to murderous Palestinian terrorism, rather than on the terrorist stabbings and shootings themselves, I wonder precisely what such people expect from Israelis? When a television presenter asks Jerusalem's mayor if carrying a gun to protect oneself from a stabbing wasn't "excessive"? Do they wish for Israelis to passively accept the terrorist's knife in their chest, and not defend themselves lest this provokes another negative headline or protest abroad?
Solidarity and sympathy with Palestinians aside, what we have witnessed these past weeks has looked like solidarity with murderous Palestinian knife-wielders, mixed with callousness towards innocent Israelis' lives.
The work of Javier Riera is based in geometric shaped light projections, striked directly onto vegetation and landscape. He uses photography as a means for registration and spreading of the happening, without digital manipulation whatsoever. Thus, it‚Äôs centered in an experience of real intervention onto ‚Äúthe space and time of the landscape‚Äù, something that approximates him to the LandArt proposals.
The relation between geometry and nature in this work adquires a meditative character, appealing for a coexistence between the public and the suggestive power of the modification of the landscape of which it is being witness, that aspires to expand its perception by reaching out towards qualities and dimensions that are hidden from the spaces in which it occurs. Riera understands geometry as a natural language previous to matter, able to establish with it a sort of subtle and revealing resonance.
In the last few years his work has broadened its records with site specific projects and temporal interventions in open spaces such as the one carried out at the gardens of Turia in Valencia, where eleven of his light projections remained installed during two months. Other interventions have been performed in MUSAC or Photoespa√±a.
Born in Avil√©s, Asturias, Javier Riera studied Fine Arts in Salamanca. Between his most important exhibitions stands out the one that took place in the Museum Reina Sof√≠a in 2008.
